title: Graduate Academic Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Public University System in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process was absolutely awful.  After several back-and-forth emails with HR (where each email was never signed off with the name of an actual human being, just simply "HR"), I had a phone interview with two different stakeholders with the university and academic advising services. 

From my perspective, the interview was going well and was mostly positive based on their responses to my answers and comments. However, halfway during the interview, the call dropped. Of course, HR never provided contact information for each interviewer. So I reached out to the generic HR. I also tried to call the interviewers back using the number that they called from (showed up on my caller ID), but the call would not go through. Long story short, I never had the chance to complete my interview. I asked twice to have that opportunity but I was told that the phone drop would not put me at an unfair advantage.

I decided to withdraw my application from the applicant pool because I cannot fathom working for a company that does not take the time to let an applicant complete an interview.
Interview Questions: All questions were STAR based.

title: Senior Manager, Accounts Payable Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Public University System
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online, 2 days later received a request for a phone interview with the Director.  A few days pass and I’m asked to come in for a face to face interview with the same director.  Another few days pass and I’m asked to provide 4 references, 2 have to be direct managers.  I was assuming that this meant an offer was coming shortly thereafter.  But no, I’m asked to come in for another interview with the actual team I’d be managing and the SVP of finance.  The team members were nice enough but less than impressive.  When I asked what they wanted from their manager, their response was basically that they wanted someone to work just like they do.  Nothing about development or anything a savvy professional would say.  Then I met with the SVP of Finance.  While she was nice enough as well, she loves to hear herself speak.  They had allotted 30 minutes with her, it went on for a little over an hour.  I might have spoken for 10 minutes.  She conveniently dropped in there that she typically works from 7am to 8pm every day and kept tying it back to how much she demands of her leaders.  Overtime was also a common theme talked about by the team members.  It was of no surprise to me that the team members weren’t interested in this leadership position, because they have no desire to work free overtime.  Can’t blame them for that.  I couldn’t even muster the ability to stretch the truth and make it appear as if I too, want to work 12 hour days for a paltry salary.  In my experience, when workers are constantly doing overtime, there are process issues that need to be fixed.  I walked away from the interview thinking the team members probably milk OT to make up for their small salaries and all they really wanted out of their manager was to help them do their work and sign off on their timesheets.  The SVP determines value by how long you’re in the office, not by what you actually do.

After the interview, I wrote professional thank you emails to both the director and SVP.  I provided feedback and my assessment for how I can help.  The team desperately needs a leader, not another worker bee.  I have vast experience improving processes that improve both employee and company performance. That’s apparently not what they want, as I never received any responses to my emails. 

I’m providing this review not because I’m upset, but to help anyone who may be looking into working in the finance department at this company.  You are going to be asked to spend a lot of your time interviewing, need to provide references, etc. only for them to completely ghost you after the fact.  Utterly unprofessional.  I get a kick out of seeing them repost this position to make it appear as if the requisition isn’t as old as it is.  Nearly 3 months later and these folks still can’t find someone to fill the role.  You would think they are looking for a rocket scientist.  

Bottom line:  Unless you are desperate, and have nothing but time at your disposal, I wouldn’t waste my time applying here.  Their pay is very low end as is their professionalism and class.
Interview Questions: Mostly situational based questions, STAR

title: Vice President Finance Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Public University System (Charles Town, WV) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions:
I was called on a Wednesday afternoon for interviews on the following day with the SVP, Operations, Chief of Staff and the Provost.  I was given no overview or prep for the position.  Two weeks later, I interviewed with the Corporate Controller and Corporate CFO.

The interviews on Thursday were very engaging and results and accomplishment oriented.  

The interview with the CFO was very different.  I found him to be arrogant, rude and condescending.  He focused on technical accounting questions which were not part of the job requirements.  I asked about significant projects and areas of focus for the upcoming year.  One of the major projects was a new front end system that two of the four interviewers had mentioned as a priority.  He was VERY put off that I knew of the project and told me I should not know about that and even lectured me.  When I asked questions about risk, he put it back to me and did not answer from his perspective.  

There seems to be a disconnect between what the CFO is looking for and what the others on the leadership team are looking for.  The position reports to the SVP of Operations not the CFO.

Questions from the initial inverview
Tell me your approach to process improvement?
Tell me about how you would go about performing a complex financial analysis.

title: Online Instructor Interview

I'm not sure how they've gotten away with this for so long, but the DOL clearly states that and there have been plenty of court cases to back it up. This is true federally, even in right to work states. I believe this information is on-topic and  meaningful to a person who is seeking to understand what it is like to work or apply at this particular company.

title: Associate Vice President - IT Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at American Public University System (Charles Town, WV) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process started out rather standard.  Very generic emails generated out of recruiting system to setup a time for phone interview.  Had interview, very easy back and forth conversation discussed my background, told me about the position, etc.  2 days later got another generic email from recruiting system to schedule an in-person interview.  After providing dates and times, received an invitation for an in-person interview scheduled for an hour.  The day of the interview I met with the CIO first, then the hiring manager.  I was there for over 3 hours which was fine, but unexpected.  I was told after that  interview that they should have a decision made within a week.  I followed up with recruiting, and a few days later got an email from an HR person saying that they're going to send me an email to provide names for an automated recruiting system.Provided the information and within 2 days had all my references provide feedback.  Nothing heard for about 2 weeks then got an email that they wanted me to meet with 3 senior staff and 3 staff that would report to me.  The interview with the most senior person was very interesting - she walked through my resume from college, through every job.  Feedback received later was that I sure moved around a lot.  (interesting because I've been with my current company for 9 years).  I was told they'd have a decision by the end of the week.  I followed up the following week and kept getting responses that we can talk tomorrow, we can talk the next day.  This went on for over 2 weeks with me waiting around for her call.  Finally I get a call from the CIO and VP of IT telling me that leadership wanted to go another direction with the focus of the position and I wasn't a fit.  However, they both felt I was a great fit for their organization and they would find me another role.
2 weeks later I get an email asking me if I was still interested in that position - to which I replied I was.  I came in the next day and spent about 1 1/2 hours discussing the position.  Next we setup 3 30 minute phone calls with the staff who would report to me for the next day.  I asked whether they were the decision makers and was told they weren't.  The following day i called into a conference bridge and had the calls with the 3 managers.  I thought the calls went very well.
Was asked Friday whether I could talk Tuesday (Monday was a holiday) and answered that I was available all day.  No call on Tuesday (which I guess is just the norm).  Wednesday AM get an email asking if we could talk in the afternoon.  Well after being 10 minutes late calling me, i was told that the staff didn't feel a connection with me.  Now I'll be honest with you - in my entire career the one thing I bring to any job is my ability to connect with people and build relationships with them.  So basically - the staff didn't want this position filled (new position between them and the VP) so they decided to block me.  What's interesting is the connection I had with both the CIO and Hiring manager was very strong and they both admitted that to me.  The staff was obviously successful, but was very surprised that the VP would let them make the hiring decision. 
I'd really watch out with this place - especially in the IT department.  If you are coming into a senior position you are at the mercy of the lower level staff.  

All in all it was a waste of time and energy.  I would have rather them say no, no thank you early on and let me move on.  Instead they dragged it out and wasted an incredible amount of my time.
Interview Questions: Please tell me about yourself
